problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: A convex lens always produces which kind of image when the object is placed *between* its focal point (F) and the lens?
problems.hint: Object inside focal point → lens cannot form a real image.
problems.detailed: When an object is between F and a convex (converging) lens, the rays diverge and the observer sees a virtual, upright, and enlarged image.

problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: For a concave mirror, if an object is placed *at* the centre of curvature (C), what is the nature of the image?
options: Image at C, same size, inverted
problems.hint: Using mirror rules: object at C gives image at C.
problems.detailed: In a concave mirror, when the object is at the centre of curvature (C), the image is also at C, is the same size as the object, and inverted and real.

problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: What happens to focal length (f) if the radius of curvature (R) of a spherical mirror is doubled?
problems.hint: Relation between focal length and radius of curvature for a spherical mirror: \(f = \frac{R}{2}\).
problems.detailed: For a spherical mirror, \(f = \frac{R}{2}\). So if radius of curvature R is doubled, focal length f also doubles.

problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: A plane mirror creates which type of image?
problems.hint: Plane mirror doesn’t converge rays, just reflects symmetrically.
problems.detailed: A plane mirror always produces a virtual, upright image that is the same size as the object, with image distance equal to object distance behind the mirror.
